body:
Yeah this was how my original Bevy UI node shader I wrote worked, with the border and node interior drawn together in one call. 
It's very hard to get the balance right between performance and flexiblity and avoiding non-degenerate geometry.

> Yeah this was how my original Bevy UI node shader I wrote worked, with the border and node interior drawn together in one call. 
> It's very hard to get the balance right between performance and flexiblity and avoiding non-degenerate geometry.
> 

Is it a big performance gain to do it this way? Does it justify the rendering not being pixel-perfect?

With regards to being flexible, do you foresee us implementing anything that benefits from having the current implementation over an implementation with a single draw call?

I am not very experienced in the rendering fields yet, so keep that in mind as I say: I prefer a stable, pixel perfect solution over one that doesn't even if that means a small decrease in performance and more code complexity. What do you think? :)

I'm not an expert on rendering either, almost everything I know comes from trial and error and lots and lots of profiling.
The main tradeoffs seem to be between the amount of data sent to the gpu each frame, the number of draw calls, the complexity of the shader program, and the number of gpu state changes.

Drawing the border and interior together is actually more performant and fixes the gaps problem as you observed, as long as you are drawing bordered nodes. But then if you use that border+interior shader to draw text you have to send border data along with it which isn't used. You can instead have a separate simpler shader to draw the text glyphs but then you have extra draw calls and state changes every time you swap the shaders.

There's also the problem that even if we draw the border + interior together we still have outlines that will show the same gaps. Maybe we should draw all three together and have a separate shader for text. 

Anyway, I think I'm sounding negative but I don't mean to be. I agree that the gaps are unnacceptable and encourage you to experiment and see if you can come up with any improvements and feel free to ping me for review if you want a second set of eyes on something.

You don't sound negative at all to me. I really appreciate your insights, thank you for that. 

I will try to implement a solution that draws the background, border and outline in one call to see how complex and performant it will be. I'll use the editor prototype the benchmark.

Looked at this again this morning and realised it's just a silly little bug. We're doing anti-aliasing across the edge of the UI nodes not on the outside of the edge and this is what causes the bleed through.

It's still worth trying out a combined border + interior shader approach though. I think we should probably switch to SDF font rendering and then a single shader for text and UI nodes wouldn't work anyway.

issue.body: # Objective Fixes #17561 ## Solution The anti-aliasing function used by the UI fragment shader is this: ```wgsl fn antialias(distance: f32) -> f32 { return saturate(0.5 - distance); // saturate clamps between 0 and 1 } ``` The returned value is multiplied with the alpha channel value to get the anti-aliasing effect. The `distance` is a signed distance value. A positive `distance` means we are outside the shape we're drawing and a negative `distance` means we are on the inside. So with `distance` at `0` (on the edge of the shape): ``` antialias(0) = saturate(0.5 - 0) = saturate(0.5) = 0.5 ``` but we want it to be `1` at this point, so the entire interior of the shape is given a solid colour, and then decrease as the signed distance increases. So in this PR we change it to: ```wgsl fn antialias(distance: f32) -> f32 { return saturate(1. - distance); } ``` Then: ``` antialias(-0.5) = saturate(1 - (-1)) = saturate(2) = 1 antialias(1) = saturate(1 - 0) = 1 antialias(0.5) = saturate(1 - 0.5) = 0.5 antialias(1) = saturate(1 - 1) = 0 ``` as desired. ## Testing ```cargo run --example button``` On main: With this PR: Modified the `button` example to draw a white background to make the bleeding more obvious.
